title: 105_s140
content: The Welfare Improvement Act of 1997, also known as the Short Title, includes provisions such as no additional cash assistance for children born to families receiving assistance, prohibition of recruitment activities, mandatory termination of assistance, work participation rate requirement, limitation on payments to States, and an effective date. Section 408(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to prohibit cash assistance for children born to families receiving assistance under the program. The Social Security Act prohibits cash assistance for children born into families receiving program benefits, with exceptions for minors with no siblings, vouchers for specific goods and services, children conceived through rape or incest, and states opting out of the program. The Social Security Act prohibits cash assistance for children born into families receiving program benefits, with exceptions for minors with no siblings, vouchers for specific goods and services, children conceived through rape or incest, and states opting out of the program. Subparagraph (A) does not apply to a State with a waiver approved by the Secretary under section 1115 allowing the denial of aid to a family due to the birth of a child to an otherwise eligible family member. The Social Security Act allows exceptions for denying cash assistance to families with children born into program benefits, including minors with no siblings, vouchers for specific goods and services, and children conceived through rape or incest. States with waivers approved by the Secretary under section 1115 can also deny aid to families due to the birth of a child to an otherwise eligible family member. SEC. 3 amends Section 1631 of the Social Security Act to prohibit recruitment activities under the title, including outreach programs or demonstration projects. SEC. 4 mandates the termination of assistance. Section 407(e)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to require individuals in a family receiving assistance to engage in work. Failure to do so will result in a reduction or termination of assistance, with exceptions allowed by the State. The state may establish and terminate assistance in the case of the third refusal. SEC. 5 amends the work participation rate requirement in the Social Security Act to increase the rate to 75%. SEC. 6 adds a limitation on payments to states in Part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. The Act imposes a limitation on payments to states under Part A of the Social Security Act, requiring states to implement random drug testing for individuals receiving assistance and terminate aid for those testing positive. The Act and its amendments are retroactively effective to the enactment of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996.
